I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Chongqing  Innovation  and  Human  Capital 
Development Project. 
 
2.   The project will (i) help the people in Chongqing gain industry-relevant and innovation-
oriented skills and capacities for employment; and (ii) support institutions to create an enabling 
and inclusive environment that helps build an innovative, diversified, efficient, and green economy 
in Chongqing. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Chongqing is a centrally administered municipality in the Chengdu–Chongqing city cluster 
at the upper reaches of the Yangtze River.1 The Yangtze River Economic Belt (YREB) is one of 
the key economic growth engines in the PRC. Its nine provinces and two specially administered 
municipalities  account for  more than  40%  of  the  PRC’s  population,  40%  of  its freshwater 
resources, and about 45% of its economic output. While the YREB, particularly in the eastern 
delta area, has benefited from extensive development since the late 1980s, economic growth in 
the middle and upper reaches of the Yangtze River basin lags behind that of the coastal areas 
and is below its potential. These parts of the YREB still face significant development challenges, 
including slow economic diversification. The YREB faces a growing imbalance between economic 
achievement and environmental quality. 
 
4.  Chongqing covers a land area of 82,400 square kilometers and has a population of more 
than 30 million, of which about 11 million are rural residents. Although Chongqing’s per capita 
gross domestic product (GDP) was slightly above the national average in 2017, it was about half 
to two-thirds that of the YREB eastern delta area.2 Chongqing was developed as one of the main 
industrial bases of the inland PRC. About 44% of Chongqing’s GDP is derived from the secondary 
industry, and the share of heavy industries (such as iron and steel, automotive, manufacturing, 
construction, and chemical industries) in the economy is high.3 Its resource-based, inefficient 
economy is impacting the environment. Chongqing’s carbon dioxide emissions per unit of GDP 
were estimated to be 7.8 tons, compared with Shanghai’s 4.0 tons or Beijing’s 3.5 tons.4 
 
5.  Chongqing’s per capita disposable income for both urban and rural residents was below 
the national average in 2017.5 The gap in income growth and industrial development between 
Chongqing and the PRC’s eastern coastal cities led to a massive population out-migration from 
Chongqing and caused severe social and economic problems; given the scarcity of matching local

2 
jobs in Chongqing, about 4.82 million people from Chongqing left their hometowns and families 
to seek work in the coastal cities or outside of Chongqing in 2017.6 The Chongqing Municipal 
Government (CMG) is under immense pressure and has issued policies and directives to support 
the  migrant  workers  to  return  to  their  hometown  in  Chongqing  for  employment  and 
entrepreneurship. However, the support mechanisms are still at the pilot stage and Chongqing 
lacks the capacity in facilitating the integration of returning migrants into the labor market and 
enhancing their access to public and social services. 
 
6.  Chongqing maintained more than 10% economic growth since 2002; however, it slowed 
to 9.3% in 2017 and further to 6.5% in 2018 because of the decline in the manufacturing and 
construction industries and insufficient capacity and human capital needed to transform from a 
traditional to an innovative economy. The CMG prioritizes innovation in promoting sustainable 
development to shift from heavily polluting industries to innovation-driven industries across all 
economic sectors.7 It aims to (i) develop intelligent and big data-related industries as the core for 
innovation-driven development; (ii) promote key emerging industries such as digital information, 
intelligent manufacturing, and alternative energy; and (iii) modernize traditional pillar industries 
and service industries. However, the skills mismatch between the local human resource supply 
and industry’s demand prevails because of a lack of relevant education and training. Among 
university or college graduates from Chongqing, only about 65% find employment in Chongqing, 
with the others mainly finding jobs in the eastern PRC. The economy and industries of Chongqing 
have been developing through imitation or replication, but the intelligent industry has no model to 
imitate. Chongqing’s innovation level was ranked 19th among 20 major PRC cities.8 
 
7.  Chongqing  has  steadily  expanded  access  to  higher  education,  which  helps  lay  an 
essential  human  resource  foundation  for  the  development  of  the  YREB’s  upper  reaches. 
However, Chongqing’s higher education institutions (HEIs) still face financial challenges; human 
resource challenges; and modern teaching and learning challenges, including the need for 
facilities to introduce and deliver new programs and courses aligned to evolving skills demands 
in the local economy.9 Challenges faced by HEIs that need to be urgently addressed include the 
following:  (i)  outdated  curricula  that  are  not  responsive  to  emerging  industrial  demands; 
(ii) teachers’ lack of technical knowledge, especially in the field of emerging technologies, and 
their lack of hands-on expertise and experience needed to teach more efficiently; (iii) the absence 
of effective institution–industry partnerships; (iv) the lack of modern interdisciplinary programs to 
cultivate and nurture students’ creativity, especially in innovation and entrepreneurship; and 
(v) the lack of facilities needed to train or retrain new skills and to introduce innovations to 
students, local skilled workers, farmers, and returning migrant workers. Local skilled workers, 
farmers, and returning migrant workers, in particular, need to continuously update their knowledge 
and gain new skills to integrate modern technologies in their jobs to improve their livelihood. 
Education programs take many years to have an impact; there is, therefore, an urgent need to 
invest now. 
 
6  The PRC had a large migrant worker population of 171.85 million in 2017. In the middle and upper reaches of the 
YREB, about 22% of the 389 million total population, or about 86 million laborers, left their hometowns and families 
to seek work in the coastal cities.

Chongqing. 
8  Evaluation of China Innovation Cities Research Group. 2016. Report on Evaluation of China Innovation Cities, 2016–
2017. Beijing (in Chinese). 
9  As of 2018, Chongqing had 65 regular HEIs. Of these, 25 were academic-track HEIs, including application-oriented 
HEIs such as Chongqing University of Science and Technology (CUST) and Chongqing University of Education 
(CUE); and 40 were tertiary technical and vocational education and training (TVET) institutions, including Chongqing 
Vocational Institute of Engineering (CVIE) (a national demonstration institution) and Chongqing Sanxia Vocational 
College (CSVC) (the only tertiary TVET institution specializing in agriculture in the YREB).

3 
8.  Industries are striving to shift to less-polluting and efficient operations through research 
and development (R&D). However, despite high returns, there is underinvestment in long-term, 
high-risk R&D activities because of limited private financial resources. Public investment in R&D 
is a crucial catalyst to boosting private R&D activities, innovations, long-term productivity, and 
economic growth. Chongqing aims to create an enabling and inclusive economic environment by 
providing public services assistance at an early stage for R&D and start-ups. Chongqing lacks 
the capacity to support business incubation; institution–industry partnerships; mentorships for 
entrepreneurs and job seekers, including returning migrant workers; intermediary services on 
legal, finance, or intellectual property; and spaces for networking and collaboration. 
 
9.  Women made up 48.6% of the total population in Chongqing in 2017. Female students’ 
representation  varies  from  16%  to  70%  in  the  project  HEIs.10 Education  patterns  remain 
segregated  along  gender  lines,  with  women  underrepresented  in  engineering,  information 
technology, and science and technology studies at all educational levels and in the workforce. 
The female entrepreneurs in the economic and technological development areas (ETDAs) in 
Changshou District and Dianjiang County account for only about 3% of all entrepreneurs in the 
ETDAs in Changshou and Dianjiang. HEIs’ female teachers and students lack knowledge and 
skills in innovation and entrepreneurship as well as the confidence to start their own businesses. 
The employment rate of returning migrants who are female is about 20% lower than that of 
returning  male  migrants.  Training  programs,  networks,  and  support  targeting  women  are 
insufficient. There is a gender imbalance in labor division—even when women start their own 
businesses, they are primarily responsible for child and elderly care and housework. 
 
10.  Chongqing lacks capacity to help create an enabling “innovation ecosystem” where HEIs 
(teachers, students, researchers, administrators, and managers); enterprises (entrepreneurs, 
engineers,  skilled  workers,  returning  migrant  workers);  intermediary  services  (business 
incubators; and professionals on legal, tax, finance, and intellectual property); and government 
(officials, policy makers, advisors) are interconnected and transfer knowledge, ideas, human and 
financial capital, and policies to provide an enabling environment for innovation and create jobs 
and benefits for both men and women. People need spaces that facilitate capacity building and 
networking to generate new ideas to start businesses. Chongqing also needs to build institutional 
capacity to manage the planned interdisciplinary capacity building activities. 
 
11.  Strategic fit. The PRC formulated the YREB development plan, which (i) stipulates 
inclusive green development to shift from a traditional subsector approach to a crosscutting 
integrated approach leading to a sustainable development model; (ii) solves the challenges of 
rapid  urbanization;  and  (iii)  serves  as  a  guide  to  socioeconomic  development.11 The  plan 
envisages the establishment of an innovative and modern industrial system in the YREB, making 
the YREB a strategic economic region for national economic and social development by 2030. 
The PRC also issued the YREB innovation-driven industrial transformation and upgrading plan in 
2016, which identifies obsolete industries and economic activities to be upgraded and diversified 
by YREB cities through entrepreneurial and innovative approaches.12 In this context, the Asian

4 
Development Bank (ADB) and the Government of the PRC have agreed to adopt a framework 
approach  to  strategically  program  ADB’s  lending  support  for  development  initiatives  in the 
YREB.13 To promote sustainable development in the upper and middle reaches of the YREB, 
ADB has worked in partnership with the central and local governments under the framework 
approach  to  explore  high-quality  development  models  for  replication.  Through  technical 
assistance projects for the YREB, ADB and the government identified two locations in the upper 
reaches of the YREB—Chongqing and Ziyang municipalities—as suitable candidates for the 
partnership.14 These two  municipalities  are  of  different  scales  and stages  of  development, 
showcasing the problems that many cities in the middle and upper reaches of the YREB are faced 
with in their economic transition to a high-quality, more inclusive development path. 
 
12.  The project is aligned with five out of the seven operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 
2030  by  enhancing  (i)  human  development  and  social  inclusion,  (ii)  gender  equality, 
(iii) greenhouse gas emissions reduction, (iv) public service provision, and (v) governance and 
institutional capacity for service delivery.15 The project is in line with ADB’s (i) education sector 
operations plan by strengthening quality, inclusiveness, and relevant skills in higher education 
and contributing to filling labor market gaps; (ii) country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–
2020 by supporting skills development and education; and (iii) country operations business plan 
for the PRC, 2019–2021, which refers to ADB’s contribution to human development to promote 
innovation and improve service delivery, and to create an enabling environment for innovation 
and new industries to support the green transformation of the local economy.16 The project 
supports the achievement of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals by supporting 
(i) inclusive and quality education; (ii) sustained, inclusive, and sustainable economic growth; 
(iii) inclusive and sustainable industrialization and fostering of innovation; and (iv) empowerment 
of women.17 
 
13.  Lessons. Key lessons from education projects in the PRC18 include (i) the need to 
establish  a  supportive  environment  for  promoting  institution–industry  cooperation, 19  and 
(ii) promotion of sustained ownership and leadership of schools and institutions for smooth 
implementation of activities and ensuring sustainability. Lessons from past and ongoing ADB 
projects in Chongqing include (i) working with the experienced Chongqing project management 
office (CPMO) at the municipal level to coordinate implementing agencies, and (ii) delegating

B. Project Description
14. The project is aligned with the following impact: sustainable and inclusive economic 
transformation in the YREB achieved (footnote 11). The project will have the following outcome: 
employment opportunities and people’s capacity for innovation in Chongqing strengthened.20
15. The project will work with seven subprojects managed by seven implementing agencies 
in Chongqing’s innovation ecosystem to pilot interventions.21 To support Chongqing’s innovation-
driven economic transformation, by 2027 the project will enable 8,000 graduates, including at 
least 25% women, to gain employment within Chongqing in strategic emerging industries, and at 
least 600 skilled technicians, including at least 25% women, working in enterprises and R&D 
institutions in Changshou and Dianjiang ETDAs to gain improved skills on entrepreneurship. 
Inclusiveness is the main feature of the project, as it considers vulnerable groups in society that 
are most affected in Chongqing’s economic transformation, including unskilled workers, returning 
migrants, farmers, and women. The project’s activities for these groups demonstrate the key 
features of an inclusive innovation ecosystem model. The project will contribute significantly to 
institutional strengthening and project sustainability.
16. Output  1:  Relevance  and  quality  of  higher  education  and  vocational  training 
strengthened.  The  project  will  educate  female  and  male  professionals  by  2026  to  have 
innovation-oriented skills and mind-sets, and promote entrepreneurial culture in project HEIs. Five 
subprojects with  five HEIs—Chongqing  Jiaotong  University (CJU),  Chongqing  University  of 
Education (CUE), Chongqing University of Science and Technology (CUST), Chongqing Sanxia 
Vocational College (CSVC), and Chongqing Vocational Institute of Engineering (CVIE)—will 
deliver output 1 through capacity development activities and provision of equipment and facilities 
to support the activities. Capacity development activities under the five subprojects will include
(i) developing  or  updating  courses  that  address  the  emerging  needs for  “green skills”  and
application of cutting-edge technologies to educate at least 30,000 students;22 (ii) developing the
abilities of at least 1,000 teachers, including women, to reform teaching resources and deliver
new courses to cultivate student’s industry-relevant and innovation-oriented skills; (iii) reforming
education to build innovative and entrepreneurial skills by creating interdisciplinary collaboration
mechanisms within HEIs and with industries, and by encouraging students, including women, to
participate in skills contests; (iv) providing lifelong learning opportunities to meet the skills and
knowledge needs for at least 60,000 local skilled workers and farmers, including women; and
(v) conducting programs such as knowledge exchanges and study visits. Four subprojects with
CJU, CUST, CSVC, and CVIE will provide (i) equipment (supported by advanced technology)
needed  for  practical  training  and  entrepreneurial  activities  developed  under  the  capacity
development activities; and (ii) green, human-centered, and gender-sensitive facilities at each
campus to provide spaces needed for practical training, R&D, teaching, and lifelong learning
activities  that  nurture  people’s  green  and  innovation-oriented  mind-sets  and  facilitate

17.  Output  2:  Supporting  mechanisms  for  innovation  and  entrepreneurship 
established.  The  project  will  work  with  two  subprojects—one  in  Changshou  (under  the 
management of the Changshou EDTA) and one in Dianjiang (under the management of the 
Dianjiang ETDA)—to deliver output 2 by 2026 through capacity development activities and 
provision  of  equipment  and  facilities  to  support  the  activities.  The  project  will  support 
(i) diversifying and modernizing Chongqing’s economy into a sustainable and innovative one; 
(ii) creating job opportunities for women and men by offering demonstration testbeds to develop 
new sustainable and competitive industries, business incubation platforms, and intermediary 
services to transform ideas into products; and (iii) supporting local workers and returning migrants’ 
needs for skills development and support. The subprojects’ capacity development activities 
include (i) development of two one-stop stations offering public services relating to business start-
ups, job opportunities, and social services (including for women); (ii) development and provision 
of at least eight training programs and mentorships to small- and medium-sized enterprises and 
female and male R&D personnel on innovation and entrepreneurship; and (iii) development and 
provision of training and mentorships to returning migrants, including at least 200 women, on skills 
development and entrepreneurship. To support the capacity development activities, the project 
will provide (i) equipment and facilities that will be used for R&D as well as for cooperation and 
collaboration to operationalize new research ideas into practice; and (ii) social and public service 
areas (e.g., one-stop stations and a daycare center for children) that support the needs of workers, 
entrepreneurs, and women. The facilities will be open to the public regularly to be demonstrated 
as green and inclusive innovation hubs. 
 
18.  Output 3: Institutional and project management capacity enhanced. The project will 
provide support by 2026 to the institutional and capacity development of the CMG, CPMO, local 
governments, and implementing agencies, including women, to (i) perform high-quality project 
management, monitoring, and reporting activities following ADB procedures and guidelines; 
(ii) ensure  the  quality  of  facilities’  design,  construction,  and  operation  and  maintenance; 
(iii) enhance  project  management  knowledge  and  skills  on  innovation  and  entrepreneurial 
activities in HEIs and ETDAs by participating in training and domestic and overseas study visits; 
and (iv) pilot green and human-centered facilities on HEI campuses and in ETDAs. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
19.  The government’s initial proposal for industrial transformation has been a conventional 
construction-based  approach.  ADB  had  numerous  consultations  with  the  CMG  and  local 
governments to encourage them to think differently to tackle their development needs, helping 
them recognize the potential for improving their capacity in promoting relevant economic sectors 
in  Chongqing  and  the  YREB.24 ADB’s  involvement  changed  stakeholders’  mind-set  and 
introduced concepts of an innovation ecosystem and innovation and entrepreneurship education 
based on best practice learned during the project preparation. The Government of the PRC and

the CMG have issued various policies and guidelines for industrial transformation and innovation, 
but their implementation has been a challenge because of the interdisciplinary nature of the 
concept. Without the ADB project, different players in Chongqing’s innovation ecosystem would 
not have the opportunity to work collaboratively across industries and sectors, which is necessary 
to catalyze inclusive green industrial transformation. 
 
20.  The programs and courses to be developed and introduced at the project HEIs will focus 
mostly  on  emerging  engineering  and  technology  fields  that  contribute  to  green  industrial 
transformation such as smart agriculture, logistics, and manufacturing; intelligent transportation 
using alternative energy sources; and safety education that will help reduce industrial pollution 
and workplace-related accidents. HEIs will adopt advanced equipment in their new education and 
training programs, including big data, virtual reality, automatic control, and three-dimensional 
printing. New courses to be introduced will adopt interdisciplinary mechanisms by integrating 
education for innovation through close partnerships between institutions and industries. 
 
21.  From the early project preparation, ADB assessed the project’s social inclusiveness. 
Chongqing’s unique socioeconomic situation requires support for returning migrant workers and 
their families, existing workers and farmers, and women. Through ADB’s involvement in the 
project design, the project became socially inclusive by extending support to various underserved 
players in Chongqing’s innovation ecosystem. This includes (i) supporting capacities of teachers 
to educate students to address social issues; (ii) providing lifelong learning opportunities to 
provide local workers, farmers, and returning migrants with new skills or bring their existing skills 
up to date; (iii) reducing out-migration and revitalizing areas in industrial decline; (iv) encouraging 
female students, workers, and teachers to participate in emerging industries and entrepreneurial 
activities; and (v) providing support to meet the needs of women, men, children, and families. 
 
22.  It is essential that the project facilities are not only designed but also constructed, 
operated, and maintained to ensure their environmental performance. With ADB’s intervention, 
the project design will consider resource efficiency and environmental protection, buildings’ life 
cycle,  human-centered  design,  and  integration  of  technology.  Facilities  will  apply  building 
information modeling and adopt intelligent systems to monitor, manage, and display the project 
facilities’ performance.25 The human-centered design promotes a healthy environment, reflects 
women’s needs, and encourages networking among people to exchange ideas that promote 
innovation. The project will provide support throughout the design, construction, and operation 
and maintenance stages to ensure quality. 
 
23.  Knowledge  sharing.  During  project  implementation,  various  available  knowledge 
platforms will be utilized to disseminate the knowledge and good practices gained from the project 
within the PRC and with Asia and the Pacific. A portion of the courses developed under the project 
will be made available online for sharing with other HEIs nationally and interested institutions in 
other developing member countries of ADB. The implementing agencies agreed to open the 
project facilities to the public regularly to demonstrate and let people experience the (i) living 
laboratories for education for sustainable development, and (ii) green innovation hubs.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
29.  The capacity building components have been designed to incorporate best practices in 
competency-based curricula and instruction, institution–industry partnerships, and innovation and 
entrepreneurship education. The project design complies with the PRC’s guidelines and local 
regulations and considers resource efficiency and environmental protection, buildings’ life cycle, 
human-centered design, and integration of technology. The recommended technologies are 
inexpensive and suitable for Chongqing’s climate. The climate risk and vulnerability assessment 
found  that  subproject  sites  would  have  medium  risk  to  climate  change  impact,  and  the

10 
implementing agencies will ensure that the detailed project designs incorporate the adjustments 
to engineering designs derived from assessment results as proactive adaptation measures. Anti-
flooding designs and evacuation devices are the principal measurements to mitigate predicted 
climate events. All project facilities shall achieve the PRC energy efficiency standards. The project 
will save 6,425 tons of carbon dioxide equivalent per year compared with the baseline scenario. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
30.  Economic. The economic analysis indicated that all the subprojects are economically 
viable, each with a positive economic net present value, and with economic internal rates of return 
above the minimum required threshold for ADB social sector projects of 9%.28 The overall 
economic internal rate of return of the project is estimated at 11.6%. The economic benefits from 
the project will mainly flow from the (i) additional job opportunities in research institutions and 
enterprises, (ii) increased productivity in the project ETDAs, and (iii) increased numbers of HEI 
graduates who will secure a job sooner.29 Additional revenue will be generated from the new 
facilities, and resource cost savings are expected because of the project’s high-quality green 
design and implementation mechanisms. Cost savings on industrial accidents averted are also 
expected from the project. Sensitivity analysis indicated that the economic viability of the project 
and its subprojects is robust to negative scenarios examined, such as delayed benefit accrual, 
benefit reduction, and increased recurrent costs. 
 
31.  Financial. Financial analysis was conducted to establish the project’s financial viability 
and sustainability.30 For the revenue-generating subprojects, the financial internal rate of return 
was compared to the weighted average cost of capital to assess viability. The Changshou 
subproject is financially viable with a financial internal rate of return of 3.4%, which exceeds the 
weighted average cost of capital of 2.0%. The Dianjiang subproject and all HEI subprojects31 are 
financially sustainable because the projected revenue exceeds the incremental cost. 
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
32.  The financial sustainability analysis shows that the fiscal burden of the subprojects in 
relation to the respective government budget is negligible. This suggests that the financial 
requirements of the subprojects are affordable for their respective implementing agencies and are 
financially sustainable. The CMG has assured ADB that it will provide the necessary counterpart 
funding to cover the project’s operation and maintenance costs and debt service repayments, in 
case any of the institutions fail to fulfill their financing requirements.

and  the  seven  implementing  agencies  have  adequate  financial  management  capacity  to 
implement  the  project.  The  financial  management  risk  is  moderate,  mainly  because  of 
implementing agencies’ lack of familiarity with ADB’s financial management and disbursement 
requirements and procedures. The risks will be mitigated by the early engagement of a financial 
management consultant and the provision of training. A financial management action plan agreed

E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
36.  A total 311,924 people will benefit from the project, comprising 151,522 direct beneficiaries 
(42% women and 3% poor) and 160,402 indirect beneficiaries (51% women and 3% poor). The 
project will (i) improve students’ capacity and employability in the labor market through access to 
quality teaching, practices, and a better learning environment in the HEIs; (ii) address supply and 
demand gaps in education and emerging business sectors; (iii) enhance teachers’ capacity to 
integrate an innovative and entrepreneurial approach into their teaching; (iv) facilitate returning 
migrants’ reintegration into the labor market and enhance their access to public and social 
services; (v) establish a support system for children in difficult situations, including migrant 
workers’ left-behind children, through relevant field research, teachers’ capacity enhancement, 
and social work service development; and (vi) make the project area economically vibrant through 
the  promotion  of  innovation  and  entrepreneurship  and  close  cooperation  among  HEIs, 
enterprises,  and  ETDAs.  The  project  is  estimated  to  create  about  5,050  jobs  during  the 
construction and operation phases for local people, including 4,820 skilled jobs (27% women) and 
230 non-skilled jobs (48% women). A social and gender action plan (SGAP) was prepared and 
its implementation will be monitored.34 
 
37.  The project is categorized gender equity theme and will significantly benefit women—who 
are disadvantaged in the labor market—mainly because of imbalanced gender labor division in 
the household. It will directly address women’s skills development and employment by narrowing 
gender disparities through access to social services, economic and financial resources, and 
opportunities. The project will benefit and empower women by enhancing women’s skills to make 
them more competitive in the labor market, encouraging their participation in economic activities 
outside the home, and supporting them in organizing their children’s care and education in newly 
established daycare centers. In the project HEIs, female teachers and students will benefit from 
the improved teaching–learning facilities, new training opportunities, and capacity building on 
innovation and entrepreneurship. The project will provide training programs for women; establish 
women’s associations to facilitate communication relating to innovation policies and support 
programs; and create employment opportunities for returning migrants and local people, including 
women with lower education and skills but with a high burden in looking after their family.

F.  Safeguards 
 
40.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.35 
 
41.  Environment (category B). An initial environmental examination and environmental 
management plan (EMP) were prepared for the project in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement, and disclosed on the ADB website. Potential environmental impacts include 
(i) dust, noise, soil runoff, and tree cutting during construction; (ii) temporary traffic disturbances 
because of transportation of construction materials; (iii) risks to community and workers’ health 
and  safety  during  construction;  and  (iv)  wastewater  and  solid  waste generated  during  the 
construction and operation. The EMP defines mitigation measures, monitoring requirements, and 
institutional responsibilities to ensure proper environmental management throughout construction 
and operation. The environmental management capabilities of the executing and implementing 
agencies were strengthened through on-the-job training and will be further enhanced by capacity 
development proposed under the project. Potential affected persons and stakeholders were 
consulted and their concerns have been incorporated in the project design and will be addressed 
through effective implementation of the EMP. The CPMO will establish a grievance redress 
mechanism. The executing agency will submit semiannual internal environmental monitoring 
reports to ADB. An external monitor will also submit semiannual monitoring reports to the 
executing agency and ADB. 
 
42.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). The project will implement seven subprojects 
with five HEIs and two ETDAs, and involve 409.9 mu of land acquisition and 10,500 square meters 
of house demolition.36 Five of the seven subprojects have completed their land acquisition, and 
their due diligence confirmed that there are no past or present concerns and outstanding 
grievances on involuntary resettlement.37 The subproject at CUE will not result in resettlement

2.5 Complete works for incubation and R&D in Q4 2021–Q2 2024. 
2.6 Implement nonstructural components in Q1 2020–Q1 2026. 
3.  Institutional and project management capacity enhanced 
3.1 Conduct knowledge-sharing activities, study tours, and policy dialogue in Q3 2020–Q3 2025. 
3.2 Conduct training on smart system and management of HEIs and ETDAs in Q4 2020–Q3 2025. 
Project Management Activities 
Engage procurement agent, design institutes, and project management consulting firm in Q1 2020–
Q2 2021. 
Design efficient project management, monitoring, and reporting system by Q4 2020. 
Engage construction supervision firm by Q1 2021. 
Monitor and evaluate project performance by establishing an efficient project management system, and 
submit project progress reports in 2020–2026. 
Implement social activities based on social and gender action plan in 2020–2026. 
Implement safeguard activities based on the environmental management plan and resettlement plans, and 
submit required monitoring reports in 2020–2026. 
Submit project completion report by Q2 2026. 
Inputs 
Asian Development Bank: €180.08 million (loan) 
Government: €226.44 million 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable 
CPMO = Chongqing project management office, ETDA = economic and technological development area, HEI = higher 
education institution, Q = quarter, R&D = research and development, RFI = results framework indicator, tCO2e = ton of 
carbon dioxide equivalent. 
a  Government of the People’s Republic of China. 2016. Outline of the Yangtze River Economic Belt Development Plan, 
2016–2030. Beijing. 
b  Social services include policy guidance and counseling on employment, entrepreneurship, social work, and 
counseling or daycare services for migrants’ families and children; and advice on investment financing, law, 
accounting, and patent applications. 
c  Emerging industries include electronic core base parts, internet of things, intelligent equipment, new materials, 
advanced transportation equipment, alternative energy and intelligent automobiles, new material, biomedicine, and 
energy  and  environmental  protection  equipment.  Chongqing  Economy  and  Information  Commission.  2016. 
Chongqing Strategic Emerging Industry, 2016–2020: Talent Demand Guidance Catalog. Chongqing (in Chinese). 
d  The estimate is based on the following assumption: not all graduates, including women, will find jobs in strategic 
emerging industries, or some will find emerging industries jobs outside Chongqing. Although the project aims to 
empower women and female students, changing mind-sets needs time. Achieving the same percentage of female 
students (as male students) who are trained to get jobs in strategic emerging industries is still challenging, as the 
project cannot force women or female students to take certain jobs, or employers to employ women. However, the 
project will significantly contribute to an increase in the number of women entering into strategic emerging industries. 
e  At the early stage of project implementation, the executing and implementing agencies, supported by the project 
management consultants, will develop detailed definition and methodologies to measure performance. 
f  The female baseline ratios are proxies estimated through consultations with the CPMO and implementing agencies. 
Exact baselines will be obtained at the early stage of the implementation. 
g  Gender-inclusive facilities are facilities that consider the specific needs of women and men, e.g., adequate lighting 
for safety, separate toilet facilities (with disabled-friendly features), and children’s daycare centers. 
Contribution to the Asian Development Bank Results Framework: 
RFI A: Jobs generated. Expected: 8,000 (2,000 female; 6,000 male). RFI B: Skilled jobs for women generated. 
Expected: 2,000. RFI C: People benefiting from improved health services, education services, or social protection. 
Expected: 12,000 (4,200 female; 7,800 male). RFI D: Total annual greenhouse gas emissions reduction (tCO2e per 
year). Expected: 6,425 tCO2e per year (resource-efficient facility design solutions at six subproject sites will result in a 
reduction of 8.57 million kilowatt-hours per annum) reduced, from 32,328 tCO2e to 25,903 tCO2e. RFI E: Service 
providers with improved performance. Expected: two (one-stop service stations established in Changshou and 
Dianjiang).
